FIRST COTILLON TO
BE DECEMBER 2
Friday night, December 2,
will be the date of the first
Cotillon of the season. The
Cotillon Club has obtained the
Maryland Casualty ballroom
for the occasion. Three dollars a couple and two dollars
stag is the price of admission.
Tickets may be obtained from
all members of the club. Music
will be provided by the Simpson-Morris Orchestra and the
dance will be from nine to
one. A buffet supper will be
served during the intermission.

AND NOW MARYLAND!
For the first time in several years the comparative records of the
Hopkins and Maryland teams will cause the two elevens to enter
the game on almost exactly even terms. In previous seasons a
superhuman showing against Yale or a remarkable record against
a number of the East's leading teams has caused Maryland to be
the overwhelming favorite. This year the situation is somewhat
different.
Despite the great advantage on paper that had been conceded
to the Ravens, Maryland's margin of supremacy for the past
four years has been only one field goal. Hopkins has played the
sort of football that Yale exhibited in the last ten minutes of the
Princeton game last Saturday. The sixty minutes were not only
a football game, but an immortal struggle.
Last year:however, with a lead of two touchdowns in the first
half, the team was not able to resist the onslaughts of one Mike
Stevens, and victory glimmered out of sight in the last few
moments of play. Some have said that the team was so intoxicated with its unexpected lead that the bubble was bound to
burst in the second half. Be that as it may, however, we have
just one word to say: Forget that the two teams are supposed
to be evenly matched. Maryland against Hopkins will no more
be the same Maryland that played Virginia than Hopkins will
be the same Hopkins that played Richmond. It will be nearly
our last chance to end a football season with a glorious gesture:
Beat Maryland!

E. E. ADAMS

Editor's note: These verses 7ciere written shortly after the close
of the lacrosse season last June, by Mr. Morrill, a member of
the team.
When at first we played Virginia
On a rainy, dismal day,
Few there were to say we would be
Champions at the end of May.
In our line-up, nine new faces—
Men who hadn't played before,
And our rooters sighed with sorrow,
Guessing sadly at the score.
Yet we won against Virginia,
Beat them bad, as Logan starred;
Nex came Yale. We tamed the bulldog,
Didn't even find them hard.
Then the third team, Randolph-Macon,
Couldn't score on us at all,
We played poorly, yet at that they
Seldom even had the ball.
West Point now was our objective,
Would they be our stumbling block?
Would our team withhold the tempest?
Were we sand or were we rock?
And back and forth that battle waged,
Like an ever swinging door,
Till the referee blew his whistle,
Hopkins-8 and Army-4.
So we journeyed homeward happy,
Light our laughter, bright our eye,
And our talk was of the future—
Navy we would beat; or die.
Before Navy came the Garnet,
With a goal-keeper of fame,
But when Hopkins finished scoring
Fifteen- goals, he'd lost h's name.
Then the seventh, and the Navy,
Navy that had trounced us when
We played them there in twenty-five,
Boasted they, "We'll win again."
Boasted they, "We'll teach these Blue Jays,
What it is to play lacrosse,
They will cease their idle chatter
When we show them we are boss."
Grim, determined for a victor
At each other's throat we flew;
Half time found us proudly leading
By the score of five to two.
Now a word of praise for Navy,
For the come-back that they staged;
N'e'er a team has played in harder
Battle than the one we waged.
But the end still found us leading,
We had sunk the Navy Blue,
Robtlson had led his teammates
To a win for J. H. U.
St. Johns next gave us no trouble,
But we viewed with great dismay
At the coming strength of Maryland,
The last team we had to play.
Beating them meant we were champions,
Champions for the second year;
But to beat them was the problem
That filled every heart with fear.
All is over now, "We're Victors!"
Yet in closing let me add,
Twelve of us are mighty happy,
Three of us are more than glad.

WHY NOT MINOR SPORTS MEN?
The Varsity Club is composed of men who have earned their
letters in major sports, but does not include the letter men of the
minor sports. If a man represents the University on an athletic
team and performs creditably enough to win the award given to
members of that team, he -has certainly done his share towards
enhancing the athletic reputation of the college.
Why, then, are members of a major sport team that does not
win a majority of its games or meets granted membership in the
club when minor sports athletes who may not lose a game or meet
all season are not members? Technically, it is true that crosscountry or tennis men are not H men, but they have, nevertheless,
represented Hopkins to the best of their ability. We cannot
understand why they are not given membership in the 'Varsity
Club.

ONCE WAS ENOUGH
In looking over the Y. M. C. A. handbook the other day, we
noticed, under the description of the Barnstormers, a line reading,
• • • It is contemplating producing genuine Hopkins plays
written and staged entirely by Hopkins talent." This makes the
third consecutive year that this "genuine Hopkins talent" has
been writing those plays. We feel sure that the poor Barnstormers weren't responsible for this bit of unwonted optimism.
Let's have a new blurb next year!

Publication, offered a five dollar Ben

Co-eds. A fair worker won the

Honorary fraternities at the University of Nebraska have been given
a severe set-back by the undergraduates of the college. Eleven social
I fraternities have withdrawn their
members from these honorary organizations, as they claim that the
honoraries are not fulfilling the purNC Poses for which they were organized and that they are detrimental
to the welfare of their members.

and the Tiger, publications at

The old question of the freedom
of. the press again confronts us—
this time at Rensselaer Polytechnic
Institute. The editor of The Polytechnic has been suspended from its
staff, and his credits for his first
three years at the college have been
c
ancelled. These actions are the
result of a, dispute over the abolishment of hazing. The action appears,
to say the
least, harsh and stringent.

There was recently made mention
in this
column of a patrol wagon
winch was purchased for vehicular
PurPoses by a certain fraternity at
Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Some practical jokers did
away with this "Black Maria" several nights ago to the consternation
atnd mystification of the brothers.
It was discovered the next morning
Parked on the city dump. Jealousy
no doubt.

DORM DOINGS
The first "Y" crusade of the
Dormitory was in the form of a
discussion group last -Wednesday
evening. The subject, "Social Relationship of Men and Women,"
attractive as it is, failed to bring
out a record crowd. However, the
few who attended the discussion
made some daring discoveries under
the leadership of E. A. Schaal.
Benarr MacFadden could have obtained sufficient material from the
general discussion to develop seven
plots for his "True Confessions"
and still have enough left over
to write several editorials for "Physical Culture." One member of
the group became so emotional that
he came through clean with his life
history. The theory that the sexual
desires can be satisfied by the love
of art and the finer things in life
was advanced. Many expressed
doubt both as to the practicability
and to the desirability of such a
theory.
Another discussion group will be
held tomorrow evening in Room
C-21 immediately following the dinner hour. All residents are cordially
invited to attend the discussion.
This week a still more daring subject will be treated by the group.
Schaal is willing to conduct the
group in the discussion of almost
any subject. The essential thing is
to obtain the group.
*

Dr. Niebuhr, Detroit Pastor to
Address Student Body,
Thursday

STETSON
HA S

Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr who will
speak at assembly this week is one
of the most prominent ministers in
this country. His topic will be
"Can Life Be Made Ethical?" This
talk should be very interesting as
the speaker is in constant touch
with current problems, being a contributor to The Atlantic Monthly,
The World of Tomorrow, and The
Christian Century.
Pastor of Detroit Church

Dr. .Niebuhr is the pastor of
Bethel Evangelical Church in Detroit, Michigan. He is a graduate
of Elmhurst College, Eden Theological Seminary, and the Yale Divinity School, and a member of the
Sigma Phi Fraternity. At present
he holds the position of Secretary
of the Fellowship for Christian Social Order.
Dr. Niebuhr is in Baltimore to
preach at Mt. Vernon Place M. E.
Church and the local Y. M. C. A.
is bringing him before the students.
Last year he was one of the outstanding speakers at the Milwaukee
National Student Conference.

Progress through co-ordination
Getting out a college paper and making telephones
have one point in common. Careful planning, persistent search for men and material, whole-hearted
cooperation among the el-tire staff—that's the spirit
that means better editing and more skilful telephone making.
This spirit is characteristic of every phase of telephone production at Western Electric. In the laboratory work, in machine design, in the cable plant
and in every other department of the great factory—
men are working together to set up new standards
and to devise more exact methods of attaining thope
standards. The result is the inevitable improvement
which marks this great industry.

A university professor has come
to the front and declared himself in
lavor of admitting to correct usage
certain expressions now termed incorrect. Professor S. A. Leonard
of the University of Wisconsin has
endorsed some of the most prevalent
ungrammatical expressions.
He
states, and rather truthfully to our
mind, that they are often clearer
and more forceful than their cultivated equivalents.

Covering subjects of two different natures, Dr. Enno Littmann,
Speyer Professor of ,Semetic languages, and the Hon. Theodore
Marburg will deliver several addresses to the public during the next
two weeks.
Dr. Littmann, who will speak today, will lecture on "The Origin of
the Arabian Nights." Mr. Marburg's address will be on the subject, "The Eighth Assembly of the
League of Nations." This lecture
will be given on November 17. The
final address will be made by Dr.
Littmann on November 29, concerning "Modern Arabic Literature."
Each of these lectures will be
given at 5 p. m. in the C. E. Hall
and are open to the public.

Historical Plays

FOR A

In the historical plays, which provided practically no latitude in the
handling of material, Shakespeare
found expression for his poetical
nature in the ennobling of his great
characters.
His first historical
play, "Richard III," which shows
the influence of Marlowe, is a pure
epic. In this play the poetical side
is uppermost to the detriment of the
realistic. But in "Richard II" he
returns to realism. Then in "Henry
IV" in the creation of Falstaff the
poetical side is expressed intensely.
Here was a triumph in comic epic
poetry. But in "Henry V" he combined the epic quality of "Richard
III" with the realistic quality of
"Henry IV" in a supreme poetical
achievement.
About 1600, as M. Feuillerat said,
Shakespeare reached the height of
his ability to combine poetry and
drama. Then, after being influenced for a while by Ben Jonson's
bitterly realistic comedies, he returned to truly poetical drama in
the almost legendary plays, "Macbeth," "Othello," "Hamlet" and
"King Lear." These, although much
like the histories, furnished far
wider opportunity for poetical
treatment. In them he achieved his
greatest success, developing his idea
of the higher purposes of the drama.
In this group the poetical element is
best seen in "King Lear," a work
of true poetry combined with moving realism.

past years usually been'on the night
before the St. John's game, but this
year it was decided to hold the affair
on the eve of the Maryland game
instead. The event is sponsored by
the entire Varsity Club, which includes the Alumni body. Mr. Alexander Randall of the Alumni Varsity Club has appointed a committee, consisting of Dave Kaufman
(chairman), Fred Bauernschmidt,
Jack Carroll and Norman Robinson,
to take care of the details of the
affair. Varsity Club members and
some special guests will be invited.
Plans are also being formulated
for the Prep school smoker, to be
held shortly after Christmas. The
outstanding pupils of the local Prep
schools will be the guests at this
affair.
Members of the Varsity Club were
entertained at the Columbia game
by Mr. J. Albert Abraham, who was
chairman of the club last year. Mr.
Abraham is at present residing in
New York. Last Saturday the St.
John's team enjoyed the hospitality
of the Varsity Club at the Athletic
Association tea dance in the afternoon.

Schiebel Runs Fourth

Captain Schiebel took fourth
place by a wide margin, being in no
danger from his nearest competitor.
Schiebel was led by John Bell of
the Millrose Club, who finished a
strong third.
Hopkins had eleven men in the
race, Stewart being scratched at the
last minute, but only eight represented the Black and Blue, as no
team was allowed to enter more
than eight men. Ten of the eleven
Jay harriers finished the race in the
following order: Gwinn, Schiebel,
Kelly, Emerson, Wheeler, Waters,
Rosser, Onorato, Yellott and Childs.
The first five Hopkins men to finish counted toward the score made
by the team. Gwinn counted 2;
Schiebel, 3; Kelly, 17; Emerson,
20, and Wheeler, 21.
Fourty-Eight Started

Ninety-eight runners entered the
event, but only 48 responded to the
starter's gun. Of these only 37
crossed the finish line, four dropping
out on the first lap. The time, 36
minutes 634 seconds, was not exceptionally fast for the distance of
six and one-sixteenth miles, which
was the length of the course.
At the end of the first lap Miller
and Ritter of the Meadowbrook
Country Club of New York, were
running first and second, with Agee
third. Gwinn and Schiebel were
well up in the first group and Kelly
was in the fore of the second. During the second lap Ritter was forced
out and Miller dropped back several places. Bell took the lead, followed immediately by Gwinn and
Schiebel. Agee stepped out in front
at the start of the last lap and was
never more than a yard or two behind during the entire lap.
Close Finishes

All the Hopkins men, except the
three leaders, were far behind during the first two laps, but gained
distance during the third. The
Jays furnished thrills for the spectators at the finish, as they staged
several beautiful rallies among
themselves.

AND NOW MARYLAND!
For the first time in several years the comparative records of the
Hopkins and Maryland teams will cause the two elevens to enter
the game on almost exactly even terms. In previous seasons a
superhuman showing against Yale or a remarkable record against
a number of the East's leading teams has caused Maryland to be
the overwhelming favorite. This year the situation is somewhat
different.
Despite the great advantage on paper that had been conceded
to the Ravens, Maryland's margin of supremacy for the past
four years has been only one field goal. Hopkins has played the
sort of football that Yale exhibited in the last ten minutes of the
Princeton game last Saturday. The sixty minutes were not only
a football game, but an immortal struggle.
Last year:however, with a lead of two touchdowns in the first
half, the team was not able to resist the onslaughts of one Mike
Stevens, and victory glimmered out of sight in the last few
moments of play. Some have said that the team was so intoxicated with its unexpected lead that the bubble was bound to
burst in the second half. Be that as it may, however, we have
just one word to say: Forget that the two teams are supposed
to be evenly matched. Maryland against Hopkins will no more
be the same Maryland that played Virginia than Hopkins will
be the same Hopkins that played Richmond. It will be nearly
our last chance to end a football season with a glorious gesture:
Beat Maryland!

E. E. ADAMS

Editor's note: These verses 7ciere written shortly after the close
of the lacrosse season last June, by Mr. Morrill, a member of
the team.
When at first we played Virginia
On a rainy, dismal day,
Few there were to say we would be
Champions at the end of May.
In our line-up, nine new faces—
Men who hadn't played before,
And our rooters sighed with sorrow,
Guessing sadly at the score.
Yet we won against Virginia,
Beat them bad, as Logan starred;
Nex came Yale. We tamed the bulldog,
Didn't even find them hard.
Then the third team, Randolph-Macon,
Couldn't score on us at all,
We played poorly, yet at that they
Seldom even had the ball.
West Point now was our objective,
Would they be our stumbling block?
Would our team withhold the tempest?
Were we sand or were we rock?
And back and forth that battle waged,
Like an ever swinging door,
Till the referee blew his whistle,
Hopkins-8 and Army-4.
So we journeyed homeward happy,
Light our laughter, bright our eye,
And our talk was of the future—
Navy we would beat; or die.
Before Navy came the Garnet,
With a goal-keeper of fame,
But when Hopkins finished scoring
Fifteen- goals, he'd lost h's name.
Then the seventh, and the Navy,
Navy that had trounced us when
We played them there in twenty-five,
Boasted they, "We'll win again."
Boasted they, "We'll teach these Blue Jays,
What it is to play lacrosse,
They will cease their idle chatter
When we show them we are boss."
Grim, determined for a victor
At each other's throat we flew;
Half time found us proudly leading
By the score of five to two.
Now a word of praise for Navy,
For the come-back that they staged;
N'e'er a team has played in harder
Battle than the one we waged.
But the end still found us leading,
We had sunk the Navy Blue,
Robtlson had led his teammates
To a win for J. H. U.
St. Johns next gave us no trouble,
But we viewed with great dismay
At the coming strength of Maryland,
The last team we had to play.
Beating them meant we were champions,
Champions for the second year;
But to beat them was the problem
That filled every heart with fear.
All is over now, "We're Victors!"
Yet in closing let me add,
Twelve of us are mighty happy,
Three of us are more than glad.

WHY NOT MINOR SPORTS MEN?
The Varsity Club is composed of men who have earned their
letters in major sports, but does not include the letter men of the
minor sports. If a man represents the University on an athletic
team and performs creditably enough to win the award given to
members of that team, he -has certainly done his share towards
enhancing the athletic reputation of the college.
Why, then, are members of a major sport team that does not
win a majority of its games or meets granted membership in the
club when minor sports athletes who may not lose a game or meet
all season are not members? Technically, it is true that crosscountry or tennis men are not H men, but they have, nevertheless,
represented Hopkins to the best of their ability. We cannot
understand why they are not given membership in the 'Varsity
Club.

ONCE WAS ENOUGH
In looking over the Y. M. C. A. handbook the other day, we
noticed, under the description of the Barnstormers, a line reading,
• • • It is contemplating producing genuine Hopkins plays
written and staged entirely by Hopkins talent." This makes the
third consecutive year that this "genuine Hopkins talent" has
been writing those plays. We feel sure that the poor Barnstormers weren't responsible for this bit of unwonted optimism.
Let's have a new blurb next year!

DORM DOINGS
The first "Y" crusade of the
Dormitory was in the form of a
discussion group last -Wednesday
evening. The subject, "Social Relationship of Men and Women,"
attractive as it is, failed to bring
out a record crowd. However, the
few who attended the discussion
made some daring discoveries under
the leadership of E. A. Schaal.
Benarr MacFadden could have obtained sufficient material from the
general discussion to develop seven
plots for his "True Confessions"
and still have enough left over
to write several editorials for "Physical Culture." One member of
the group became so emotional that
he came through clean with his life
history. The theory that the sexual
desires can be satisfied by the love
of art and the finer things in life
was advanced. Many expressed
doubt both as to the practicability
and to the desirability of such a
theory.
Another discussion group will be
held tomorrow evening in Room
C-21 immediately following the dinner hour. All residents are cordially
invited to attend the discussion.
This week a still more daring subject will be treated by the group.
Schaal is willing to conduct the
group in the discussion of almost
any subject. The essential thing is
to obtain the group.
*

*

Dr. Niebuhr, Detroit Pastor to
Address Student Body,
Thursday

STETSON
HA S

Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr who will
speak at assembly this week is one
of the most prominent ministers in
this country. His topic will be
"Can Life Be Made Ethical?" This
talk should be very interesting as
the speaker is in constant touch
with current problems, being a contributor to The Atlantic Monthly,
The World of Tomorrow, and The
Christian Century.
Pastor of Detroit Church

Dr. .Niebuhr is the pastor of
Bethel Evangelical Church in Detroit, Michigan. He is a graduate
of Elmhurst College, Eden Theological Seminary, and the Yale Divinity School, and a member of the
Sigma Phi Fraternity. At present
he holds the position of Secretary
of the Fellowship for Christian Social Order.
Dr. Niebuhr is in Baltimore to
preach at Mt. Vernon Place M. E.
Church and the local Y. M. C. A.
is bringing him before the students.
Last year he was one of the outstanding speakers at the Milwaukee
National Student Conference.

The "Y" discussion groups are
apparently attempting to put Group
X or A. N. 1 out of business. To
prevent such a disaster the members
of Kappa Chi have loyally pledged
themselves to the support of Group
X. There will be a formal pledging of new members to Kappa Chi
in the courtyard of the Dormitory
next week. The activities of KX
were temporarily suspended until
after the rushing season, as a matter
of courtesy to the fraternities represented on the interfraternity
board. KX will get hot from now
until Christmas, then another period
of suspended activities will result in
honor of mid-years. KX has fostered an investigation made in the
interest of pure science. Unfortunately the results of the unique experiment must remain unknown to
all but good and true KX's.

All of the entries have now elected
their members to represent them on
the Board of Governors. Only in
a few instances were the elections
hotly contested affairs. In most
entries the representatives were
elected either by an overwhelming
majority or by an unanimous vote.
Original and effective measures
were employed to secure votes.
The entry "B" boys instructed the
freshmen of that entry that they
were to vote for Buck Brawner and
Jerry Natt for representatives under
penalty of persuasive paddling. The
warning was posted on the entry
door. Buck and Jerry are on the
Board of Governors. When consulted as to the results of the elections, Joe Dorm said, "I feel that
the best men have been elected."

Progress through co-ordination
Getting out a college paper and making telephones
have one point in common. Careful planning, persistent search for men and material, whole-hearted
cooperation among the el-tire staff—that's the spirit
that means better editing and more skilful telephone making.
This spirit is characteristic of every phase of telephone production at Western Electric. In the laboratory work, in machine design, in the cable plant
and in every other department of the great factory—
men are working together to set up new standards
and to devise more exact methods of attaining thope
standards. The result is the inevitable improvement
which marks this great industry.

PROFESSOR FEUILLART
LECTURES AGAIN

A university professor has come
to the front and declared himself in
lavor of admitting to correct usage
certain expressions now termed incorrect. Professor S. A. Leonard
of the University of Wisconsin has
endorsed some of the most prevalent
ungrammatical expressions.
He
states, and rather truthfully to our
mind, that they are often clearer
and more forceful than their cultivated equivalents.

Two men at the University of
California are earning their way
through college by caring for babies
While the parents are away. Many
Other novel means for earning
money are practiced by impecunious
students at California. Three of
themn are motormen, several operate taxis, and two act as interpreters
for German moving picture stars
liViug in Hollywood.

Heavy streams of water were
n ecessary to quell the freshmansophomore riot at Crabtown
last
Year, but the students of Georgia
Tech went us one better Saturday
night by forcing the police to use
tear
bombs in breaking up the celebration in honor of Tech's vicfory
over Alabama. The undergraduates picked up automobiles, turned
theni around, a,nd bounced them up
and down. They crippled the trolley lines and staged a wild bread
fight. The police were going to
Stop the
riot by the use of water,
but decided to use the less disagreeable tear bombs instead.

The honor system at the University of
California is again in working order. The famous "gentleinen's code" of California was seriously,
threatened last year by an
lesPidemic of cheating and it almost
"ecame necessary to do away with
student self-government and the
honor system. Now the honor syst_ein is working better than ever betore and the rule requiring students
to
sign a pledge at the bottom of
their
papers has been rescinded.

Covering subjects of two different natures, Dr. Enno Littmann,
Speyer Professor of ,Semetic languages, and the Hon. Theodore
Marburg will deliver several addresses to the public during the next
two weeks.
Dr. Littmann, who will speak today, will lecture on "The Origin of
the Arabian Nights." Mr. Marburg's address will be on the subject, "The Eighth Assembly of the
League of Nations." This lecture
will be given on November 17. The
final address will be made by Dr.
Littmann on November 29, concerning "Modern Arabic Literature."
Each of these lectures will be
given at 5 p. m. in the C. E. Hall
and are open to the public.

Historical Plays

FOR A

In the historical plays, which provided practically no latitude in the
handling of material, Shakespeare
found expression for his poetical
nature in the ennobling of his great
characters.
His first historical
play, "Richard III," which shows
the influence of Marlowe, is a pure
epic. In this play the poetical side
is uppermost to the detriment of the
realistic. But in "Richard II" he
returns to realism. Then in "Henry
IV" in the creation of Falstaff the
poetical side is expressed intensely.
Here was a triumph in comic epic
poetry. But in "Henry V" he combined the epic quality of "Richard
III" with the realistic quality of
"Henry IV" in a supreme poetical
achievement.
About 1600, as M. Feuillerat said,
Shakespeare reached the height of
his ability to combine poetry and
drama. Then, after being influenced for a while by Ben Jonson's
bitterly realistic comedies, he returned to truly poetical drama in
the almost legendary plays, "Macbeth," "Othello," "Hamlet" and
"King Lear." These, although much
like the histories, furnished far
wider opportunity for poetical
treatment. In them he achieved his
greatest success, developing his idea
of the higher purposes of the drama.
In this group the poetical element is
best seen in "King Lear," a work
of true poetry combined with moving realism.

Gives Permission for Party
Before Maryland Game

TRANSPORTATION
Official permission for the annual
Varsity Club party has been given
by Dean Ames. The party will be
held on Wednesday night, November 23, in the Civil Engineering
Hall. The date of the party has in
past years usually been'on the night
before the St. John's game, but this
year it was decided to hold the affair
on the eve of the Maryland game
instead. The event is sponsored by
the entire Varsity Club, which includes the Alumni body. Mr. Alexander Randall of the Alumni Varsity Club has appointed a committee, consisting of Dave Kaufman
(chairman), Fred Bauernschmidt,
Jack Carroll and Norman Robinson,
to take care of the details of the
affair. Varsity Club members and
some special guests will be invited.
Plans are also being formulated
for the Prep school smoker, to be
held shortly after Christmas. The
outstanding pupils of the local Prep
schools will be the guests at this
affair.
Members of the Varsity Club were
entertained at the Columbia game
by Mr. J. Albert Abraham, who was
chairman of the club last year. Mr.
Abraham is at present residing in
New York. Last Saturday the St.
John's team enjoyed the hospitality
of the Varsity Club at the Athletic
Association tea dance in the afternoon.

Schiebel Runs Fourth

Captain Schiebel took fourth
place by a wide margin, being in no
danger from his nearest competitor.
Schiebel was led by John Bell of
the Millrose Club, who finished a
strong third.
Hopkins had eleven men in the
race, Stewart being scratched at the
last minute, but only eight represented the Black and Blue, as no
team was allowed to enter more
than eight men. Ten of the eleven
Jay harriers finished the race in the
following order: Gwinn, Schiebel,
Kelly, Emerson, Wheeler, Waters,
Rosser, Onorato, Yellott and Childs.
The first five Hopkins men to finish counted toward the score made
by the team. Gwinn counted 2;
Schiebel, 3; Kelly, 17; Emerson,
20, and Wheeler, 21.
Fourty-Eight Started

Ninety-eight runners entered the
event, but only 48 responded to the
starter's gun. Of these only 37
crossed the finish line, four dropping
out on the first lap. The time, 36
minutes 634 seconds, was not exceptionally fast for the distance of
six and one-sixteenth miles, which
was the length of the course.
At the end of the first lap Miller
and Ritter of the Meadowbrook
Country Club of New York, were
running first and second, with Agee
third. Gwinn and Schiebel were
well up in the first group and Kelly
was in the fore of the second. During the second lap Ritter was forced
out and Miller dropped back several places. Bell took the lead, followed immediately by Gwinn and
Schiebel. Agee stepped out in front
at the start of the last lap and was
never more than a yard or two behind during the entire lap.
Close Finishes

All the Hopkins men, except the
three leaders, were far behind during the first two laps, but gained
distance during the third. The
Jays furnished thrills for the spectators at the finish, as they staged
several beautiful rallies among
themselves.
